questions.question: A spring ($k = 550 \text{ N/m}$) stores exactly 4.4 J of elastic potential energy. By how many centimeters has the spring been displaced from its equilibrium position?
A spring has an original length of 15.0 cm and a spring constant of 900 N/m. If 1.8 J of work is done to compress the spring, what is its new total length?
A 4.5 kg mass is hung from a vertical spring ($k = 220 \text{ N/m}$) with an original length of 0.30 m. Find the new total length of the spring when the mass is at rest. (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)
How much force is required to compress a spring ($k = 750 \text{ N/m}$) to the point where it stores exactly 15.0 J of elastic potential energy?
A spring is initially stretched by 3.0 cm. If the extension is increased so that the new total extension is 12.0 cm, by what factor has the stored elastic potential energy increased?
A spring with a constant of 180 N/m is already stretched 10.0 cm from equilibrium. How much additional work is required to stretch the spring to a total extension of 25.0 cm?

A 4.0 kg block starts from rest at the top of a frictionless incline 6.0 m high. At the bottom, it transitions to a horizontal surface with a coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k = 0.25$. Calculate the total horizontal distance the block travels before coming to a stop. (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)

A 1.5 kg block is pressed against a horizontal spring ($k = 600\text{ N/m}$), compressing it by 20.0 cm. When released, the block moves across a horizontal surface with $\mu_k = 0.30$. How far does the block travel from the point of release? (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)

A 10.0 kg crate is traveling at 6.0 m/s on a horizontal surface. It encounters a rough patch 2.0 m long ($\mu_k = 0.35$) before hitting a spring ($k = 2000\text{ N/m}$). Determine the maximum compression of the spring after the crate has passed through the rough patch. (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)

A 2.0 kg block slides down a frictionless incline from a height of 5.0 m. It then travels 3.0 m across a rough horizontal surface ($\mu_k = 0.20$) before striking a horizontal spring ($k = 500\text{ N/m}$). Calculate the maximum compression of the spring. (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: $PE = 2 \times 10 \times 5 = 100$ J. $E_{lost} = \mu_k mg d = 0.20 \times 20 \times 3 = 12$ J. $E_{spring} = 88$ J ⇒ $\frac{1}{2} \times 500 \times x^2 = 250x^2 = 88$ ⇒ $x^2 = 0.352$ ⇒ $x = 0.593$ m.
